bibl.title: Military Orders for Robert P. Cooke, November 19, 1900

div1.p: Special Orders #272 revokes Special Order #265 for Cooke. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Robert P. Cooke, November 19, 1900
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec orders
Vol 2 1900
Cooke - Hepburn

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 272. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, November 19, 1900.

1. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, paragraph 7,
Special Orders, No. 267, November 13, 1900, from this office,
relating to Electrician Sergeant Ernest Dieckhoff, Fort Sam
Houston, Texas, is amended to read, “will report upon arrival
to the commandant of that school for instruction.”

2. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Recruits
Edward J. Bartlett, Guy Pickles, and Theodore Wettach, gen-
eral service, Presidio of San Francisco, California, will be dis-
charged from the Army by the commanding officer of that
post, by reason of being unsuited to the service. These
soldiers are entitled to travel-pay.

3. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Private
Earl W. Edwards, Battery O, 4th Artillery, Fort Hancock,
New Jersey, will be discharged from the Army, by way of
favor, by the commanding officer of his station. This soldier
is not entitled to travel-pay.

4. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Private
Charles S. Dickerson, general service, Columbus Barracks,
Ohio, will be sent to the general hospital, Fort Bayard, New
Mexico, reporting upon arrival to the commanding officer for
treatment in the hospital. The commanding officer, Columbus
Barracks, Ohio, will forward by mail to the commanding
officer of the hospital at Fort Bayard the descriptive list and
account of pay and clothing of the soldier prior to his depar-
ture from that post.

5. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Privates
Archie M. Gibson, Troop I, 4th Cavalry; Aug Tross, Com-
pany A, 12th Infantry; William J. Propster, Company C,
21st Infantry; John Lattimore, general service; James A.
Reese and Loren Yost, Hospital Corps, now in this city, hav-
ing performed the duties assigned them in paragraph 2, Spe-
cial Orders, No. 211, Army General Hospital, Presidio of San
Francisco, California, November 13, 1900, will return to their
proper station, with permission to delay thirty days en route.
The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the necessary
3
the United States by the Acting Secretary of War, to take
effect November 30, 1900, his services being no longer required.
He will proceed to his home. The travel enjoined is necessary
for the public service.

14. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, paragraph
14, Special Orders, No. 263, November 8, 1900, from this office,
is amended to read as follows: By direction of the Acting
Secretary of War, Acting Assistant Surgeon Carle E. Bentley,
U. S. Army, in addition to his duties at Fort Logan H. Roots
will perform the duties of examiner of recruits at Little Rock,
Arkansas.

15. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, so much
of paragraph 10, Special Orders, No. 265, November 10, 1900,
from this office, as relates to Acting Assistant Surgeon Robert
P. Cooke, U. S. Army, is revoked.
✓

16. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the follow-
ing assignments to regiments of officers recently promoted are
made:

Lieutenant Colonel James Miller (promoted from major,
22d U. S. Infantry), to the 19th U. S. Infantry, to date from
November 13, 1900, vice Boyle, retired from active service.
Major Miller will proceed to join his regiment.

Major Richard T. Yeatman (promoted from captain, 3d U. S.
Infantry), to the 22d U. S. Infantry, to date from November 13,
1900, vice Miller, promoted. Major Yeatman will proceed to
join his regiment.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

17. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, leave of
absence for ten days, to take effect on or about November 30,
1900, is granted Captain Samuel W. Dunning, 16th U. S. In-
fantry, recruiting officer.

18. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Captain
William S. Biddle, jr., 14th U. S. Infantry, will take tempo-
rary charge of the recruiting offices at Detroit, Michigan, and
Toledo, Ohio, during the absence on leave of Captain Samuel
W. Dunning, 16th U. S. Infantry, and will visit Toledo, Ohio,
on recruiting duty not to exceed once in five days. Such jour-
neys as may be necessary for Captain Biddle to make in visit-
ing Toledo, Ohio, and returning to Detroit, Michigan, and be-
tween Fort Wayne and Detroit, Michigan, are necessary for
the public service.

19. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, paragraph
16, Special Orders, No. 267, November 13, 1900, from this office,
is so amended as to direct Acting Assistant Surgeon Erwin I.
Shores, U. S. Army, upon being relieved from duty at Fort
Caswell, North Carolina, by Acting Assistant Surgeon James
H. Hepburn, U. S. Army, to proceed to his home, West Bridge-
water, Massachusetts, and upon arrival report by letter to the
Surgeon General of the Army for annulment of contract. The
travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
BY COMMAND OF LIEUTENANT GENERAL MILES:

H. C. CORBIN,
Adjutant General.
Army Hdqrs.
